hints.content: Start by understanding what a subarray is. A subarray is a contiguous part of the array. For example, in the array [1, 2, 3], the subarrays are [1], [2], [3], [1, 2], [2, 3], and [1, 2, 3].
Consider how to calculate the GCD of a set of numbers. The GCD of two numbers can be found using the Euclidean algorithm. For multiple numbers, you can iteratively apply the GCD function.
Think about how you can iterate through all possible subarrays. You can use two nested loops: the outer loop to fix the starting point and the inner loop to extend the subarray to the end.
When checking the GCD of a subarray, remember that if the GCD of the subarray is not equal to k, you can skip counting that subarray. Keep track of the current GCD as you extend the subarray.
Before you start iterating, filter the array to only include elements that are multiples of k. This is because if any element in the subarray is not a multiple of k, the GCD cannot be k.
As you iterate, maintain a count of valid subarrays. Each time you find a subarray with a GCD of k, increment your count.
Consider edge cases, such as when the array contains only one element. If that element is equal to k, it should count as a valid subarray; otherwise, it should not.
Remember that the GCD can only be equal to k if all elements in the subarray are at least k. You might want to check for this condition while iterating.
To optimize, once you find a subarray where the GCD is k, you can potentially break out of the inner loop early if extending the subarray further would not yield a GCD of k.
Finally, ensure your function returns the count of valid subarrays. You might want to return the count at the end of your function after all iterations are complete.

questionNotes: Subarrays must be contiguous and non-empty.
The GCD of the subarray must be exactly equal to k.
